prepRecipe.method: Makes 300ml: This is the Milk and Honey recipe.
Lightly toast 220g of slivered almonds in the oven. They toast quick, do not burn them.
Grind the almonds in a food processor to a coarse powder.
Add 300g white sugar and 200ml water into a pot and bring to a boil over low heat stirring constantly.
Add the ground toasted almonds and cook for another 3 minutes while continuing to stir.
Remove from heat and cover. Let sit for up to 6 hours.
Transfer the syrup to a jelly bag or nut bag and strain into a spouted measuring cup.
Add 1 oz.(30ml) vodka and 1 teaspoon orange flower water and stir to combine.
Cover and refrigerate. Keeps for about a month.
Measure out 200g water and 50g of gum arabic powder and whisk together at room temp for a couple of minutes.
The easier way to do this is with time, by letting it sit for 8 hours or so until the gum arabic is dissolved.
If you're on a time crunch, you can use hot water and whisk it together for ten minutes like your life depends on it. Though, you'll still have to let it sit for a couple of hours to fully dissolve.
Pour your gum arabic and water solution in a saucepan over very low heat and add 200g of sugar, one cup of pineapple chunks, and two tablespoons of pineapple juice.
Stir the sugar into the solution until all the sugar has dissolved. If you want a rich 2:1 syrup, just double up on the sugar but use the same amount of gum arabic. Don't let it come to a boil!
Let it cool before straining and bottling.
This will keep for about a month in the fridge.
Add 45g of Jasmine tea to one 750ml bottle of Woody Creek gin.
Shake after 30 min
strain after an hour and twenty minutes
For 500ml: Add 250g white sugar to 150g of orange peels.
Let sit in a mason jar for 24 hours in a semi-warm place. This will be our oleo saccharum.
Add 250g fresh clementine juice and shake until the oleo is completely emulsified.
Strain the peels out. Keeps for 1 week in the fridge.

instructions.method: Heat your Blue Blazer mugs and toddy glass with boiling water. Place the whisky in the small tin in a large tin on top of the boiling water.
After your glass is sufficiently warm, dump the old water and add two oz. of fresh hot water to your toddy glass.
Add the bitters, lemon peel, and sugar cubes and muddle.
Pour out the hot water from the blue blazer mugs leaving two oz. of hot water in one.
Add the over-proof scotch to the hot water in one of the mugs. The trick here is to have a scotch that's over 54% ABV.
tilt the mug and set ablaze.
With the handles point towards your body, hold the mugs like you would hold a gun. This is a Sean Kenyon tip.
Start the transfer of fiery liquid from one mug to the other slowly and with little distance between the two, gradually increasing the distance with each pull.
After ten plus pulls, and when everyone is sufficiently dazzled, the toddy should be ready to transfer to your glass.

prepRecipe.method: Measure out 200g water and 50g of gum arabic powder and whisk together at room temp for a couple of minutes.
The easier way to do this is with time, by letting it sit for 8 hours or so until the gum arabic is dissolved.
If you're on a time crunch, you can use hot water and whisk it together for ten minutes like your life depends on it. Though, you'll still have to let it sit for a couple of hours to fully dissolve.

Pour your gum arabic and water solution in a saucepan over very low heat and add 200g of sugar. Stir the sugar into the solution until all the sugar has dissolved. If you want a rich 2:1 syrup, just double up on the sugar but use the same amount of gum arabic. Don't let it come to a boil!

This will keep for several weeks in the fridge.

prepRecipe.method: For 500ml: Combine 250g of water, 250g of white sugar, and one whole vanilla bean (or one tablespoon vanilla extract or vanilla bean paste but these options are not preferred) into a pot.
Heat on a stove top until it comes to a boil and immediately turn the heat off.
Let it rest for about twenty minutes checking the flavor every ten minutes. if you like a stronger vanilla flavor, let it steep longer. Take the vanilla bean out when you've found the right flavor.
Let it cool and strain before bottling.
If you used a bean paste, strain the syrup through a coffee filter.

prepRecipe.method: This is Julie Reiner's recipe. Weigh out one part raspberries to two parts sugar and add them to a pot.
Get some gloves on a smash the berries and sugar together. This is easiest with your hands, but if you don't have gloves you can use a spatula or a muddler.
Let it macerate for one to two hours
Add the same weight of the raspberries of water.
Give it a quick stir and put it all on low heat, stirring occasionally.

You want the lowest heat possible here, just so the sugar dissolves. Do not let it come to a boil or you will ruin the bright floral flavor of the raspberries. This shouldn't take longer than 10 minutes.
Take off heat as soon as you can and let cool before straining the pulp out of the syrup and bottling.

notes: The original Clover Club was a gentleman's club in Philadelphia from 1882-1920s, where the cocktail originated.

instructions.method: Combine the lime wedges, cucumber, simple syrup, and gin in a cocktail shaker and muddle to extract the juice from the lime without pulverizing the fruit.

Build in glass.
Float the Galliano

notes: This is a built cocktail that gained popularity through a marketing campaign from George Bednar for McKesson Imports(Galliano's importer at the time). Though, the drink itself was likely the of bartender Donato 'Duke' Antone, who may have been serving it since the 1950s at the Hollywood bar Black Watch, calling it the 'Duke Screwdriver'. Bednar picked it up in the the late 60s and built an advertising campaign around it for McKesson. It goes to show you that even if the cocktail is total trash, as long as its easy to make and there's tons of advertising behind it, it has a chance to make it into the history books and people like us, who dedicate their entire careers to perfecting their craft, end up writing about it.

Combine all ingredients, except for the Ardbeg Scotch, into a mixing glass with ice and stir.
Rinse your stemmed glassware with the ardbeg.
Strain the cocktail into the prepared glass.

notes: The original cocktail stemmed from the Daiquiri No. 3 at La Floridita, which actually was one of the first blended Daiquiris to ever exist as Constantino 'Constante' Ribalaigua was utilizing the latest technology that existed at the time, the blender. Hemingway loved the cocktail but asked for it with no sugar and double the rum making it an insanely tart and punchy cocktail. The cocktail is unbalanced but I think it's important to understand where this cocktail came from and why it exists.

prepRecipe.method: Measure out 200g water and 50g of gum arabic powder and whisk together at room temp for a couple of minutes.
The easier way to do this is with time, by letting it sit for 8 hours or so until the gum arabic is dissolved.
If you're on a time crunch, you can use hot water and whisk it together for ten minutes like your life depends on it. Though, you'll still have to let it sit for a couple of hours to fully dissolve.

Pour your gum arabic and water solution in a saucepan over very low heat and add 200g of sugar. Stir the sugar into the solution until all the sugar has dissolved. If you want a rich 2:1 syrup, just double up on the sugar but use the same amount of gum arabic. Don't let it come to a boil!
Let it cool before bottling. If there's still some gum arabic floating around, you'll want to strain it out before bottling.
This will keep for several weeks in the fridge.

add ice to the rim of the cup and stir a couple of more times.

notes: This is one of the oldest cocktails to exist. This is a style of cocktail that came from a long rich history of the 'Julep' dating back to the early 1700s. This whiskey version didn't come to prominence until the mid 1800s. The Kentucky Derby didn't claim it until the 1930's. That being said, this cocktail is almost impossible to credit one person or place for its invention.

prepRecipe.method: Makes 300ml: This is the Milk and Honey recipe.
Lightly toast 220g of slivered almonds in the oven. They toast quick, do not burn them.
Grind the almonds in a food processor to a coarse powder.
Add 300g white sugar and 200ml water into a pot and bring to a boil over low heat stirring constantly.
Add the ground toasted almonds and cook for another 3 minutes while continuing to stir.
Remove from heat and cover. Let sit for up to 6 hours.
Transfer the syrup to a jelly bag or nut bag and strain into a spouted measuring cup.
Add 1 oz.(30ml) vodka and 1 teaspoon orange flower water and stir to combine.
Cover and refrigerate. Keeps for about a month.

notes: The original cocktail, dating somewhere around 1912, was a bottled sling called the 'Pimms No. 1 Cup'. It was kinda like what we know of today as an RTD, but without the carbonation or citrus. We now know of Pimms as the liquor that more or less resembles an Amaro. All the modern versions of this cocktail are restoritive and refreshing. The widely recognized version of the Piña Colada today is a blended frozen cocktail that originated with the creation of Coco Lopez in Puerto Rico. It is regarded as their signature drink. The term 'Piña Colada' translates to 'strained pineapple.' According to Dave Wondrich, prior to Coco Lopez, the Piña Colada was a Cuban non-alcoholic refreshment. It's likely that Cubans also mixed rum into it, representing one of those seemingly inevitable combinations that obscure its true origin. To prepare this version, you'll need approximately 250ml of crushed ice to blend with the other ingredients.

instructions.method: NOTE: A very important variable here is a high fat content heavy cream. If you can find something in the 40% range, it's worth it's weight in gold.
Chill your 14oz. collins glass ahead of time
Add all of the ingredients, except for the soda, into a tin along with two Kold Draft cubs, or their equivalent weight in alternative ice (roughly 16g).
Shake vigorously until the Ice cubes completely dissolve.
Add the soda to the chilled glass.

Give the tin a couple more shakes to re-emulsify then pop the tin and strain the cocktail over the soda as quickly as possible (the forceful motion of the cocktail getting added to the soda creates the initial reaction that you need to form the head). Fill until the head touches the top of the glass. There should be 2-4oz. of liquid left in the tin. Put it aside for step 7.

Be patient. Let the cocktail sit for a minute or two so that the head can properly separate from the rest of the cocktail. After you see a clear separation, place the teardrop end of the bar spoon down the center of the cocktail. This will serve as a guide for the rest of the cocktail to be added.

Pour the rest of the cocktail from the tin down the guide. Be careful so that you don't disturb the head of the cocktail. if you need more liquid to push the head further up above the rim, add more soda to the tin and repeat this step until you have your desired height.
Add three drops of orange flower water to the top of the cocktail. Garnish with orange zest.
NOTE: This is Williams and Graham spec. The original was made slightly different but in a similar vein and with the same ingredients.

notes: The cocktail was not Fleming's creation. It was devised by his friend Ivar Bryce as evidenced by the words Fleming inscribed in Bryce's copy of Casino Royale: 'For Ivar, who mixed the first Vesper and said the good word.'Naming a cocktail the Vesper was Fleming's idea though he drew inspiration from someone else's joke. He had encountered the term at evening drinks when a butler announced: 'Vespers are served.' Fleming adapted this pun on the name of the religious observance normally held about sunset, 'Vespers'. And Bond alludes to this by praising his cocktail's name as 'very appropriate to the violet hour when my cocktail will now be drunk all over the world.'Just as the character Vesper Lynd dies in Casino Royale, the cocktail named for her makes no appearance in any of Fleming's later Bond novels. Fleming, in a letter to The Guardian in 1958, said that when he tasted a Vesper for the first time several months after including it in his novel, he found it 'unpalatable'.

Let cool before bottling.
